node.title: Why Black Friday is becoming the most wonderful time of the year for retailers
node.description: November has now outpaced December as the biggest retail trading month of the year and shoppers are planning to spend even more this Black Friday and Cyber Monday in an effort to get gifts in time for Christmas.

node.title: Three men found guilty of murder of unarmed black man Ahmaud Arbery in US
node.description: Three white men on trial over the shooting of unarmed black man Ahmaud Arbery in the US have been convicted of murder.

node.title: When Reader Meets Writer
node.description: A dig into the archives for those magical moments at author signings.

node.title: Men Found Guilty of Killing Arbery Head to Federal Court in 10 Weeks on Hate Crime Charges
node.description: Federal prosecutors have charged the three men with interfering with Arbery's civil rights and attempting to kidnap the Black jogger "because of his race."

node.title: Cook Fired for Writing 'Let's Go Brandon' on School Menu Sign, Leaving Job Early
node.description: "[T]his is about taking advantage of a profane euphemism in an elementary school," a superintendent said of the placement of the phrase.

node.title: Every morning Andrew woke to the sound of his cellmate on the toilet
node.description: Prisoners are forced to use the toilet in front of cellmates, a new report says, because the Tasmanian government is dealing with growing numbers by adding beds to single cells not designed for them.

node.title: Former person of interest in Willam Tyrrell case says new search brought back painful memories
node.description: The pensioner says he was "humiliated" by detectives investigating the disappearance of William Tyrrell and is considering suing police over his treatment.

node.title: 3 men found guilty of murdering Ahmaud Arbery
node.description: Travis McMichael, his father Gregory McMichael and their neighbor William "Roddie" Bryan each faced nine felony counts.

node.title: C.D.C. Eases Up on Dog Travel Ban
node.description: The agency will now allow some pets to be brought back into the United States from 113 countries considered as high risk for rabies.

node.title: U.N. Official Says Iran Trip Made No Progress in Learning About Nation's Nuclear Program
node.description: The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency traveled to meet the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran but reported no breakthrough in negotiations.

node.title: School Tells Mask-Exempt Students to Wear Yellow Star Resembling Holocaust Symbol
node.description: A co-founder of a parent campaign group called the move "deeply inappropriate."

node.title: Obituary Requests 'Irresponsibly Large Wager' Be Placed on Nebraska Game, People Deliver
node.description: "If the ghost of my old man can't will the Huskers to victory on Friday," said Todd Munson, "then they truly are a lost cause."

node.title: Gregory and Travis McMichael, William Bryan Guilty of Murder in Ahmaud Arbery Case
node.description: The three men had been accused of chasing Arbery with their pickup trucks and killing him with a 12-gauge shotgun.

node.title: Rescue mission underway after 31 people die in English Channel boat capsize
node.description: At least 31 people die when a dinghy filled with migrants capsizes in the English Channel in what officials describe as the worst disaster involving migrants to occur in the waterway.

node.title: Collins demotes Simon Bridges over allegation of misconduct
node.description: National's leader Judith Collins has demoted Simon Bridges following an accusation he made inappropriate comments to a female National MP several years ago.

node.title: Jury reaches verdict in the killing of Ahmaud Arbery
node.description: Travis McMichael, his father Gregory McMichael and their neighbor William "Roddie" Bryan each faced nine felony counts.

node.title: ‘A Castle for Christmas’ Review: Deck the Halls With Expensive Tartans
node.description: Charming locals in Scotland can’t save Brooke Shields and Cary Elwes from the script of this formulaic holiday rom-com.

node.title: ATP Finals Create a Buzz in Turin, but Will Italy’s Players Follow?
node.description: Turin is a smaller stage than the prestigious event had in London, but the enthusiasm was real, especially for the young Italian stars Jannik Sinner and Matteo Berrettini.

node.title: ‘A Moral Imperative, an Economic Necessity’: Parents Speak Out About Paid Leave
node.description: Parents told us what having paid parental leave — or not — meant for their families.

node.title: Trump Investigation Enters Crucial Phase as Prosecutor’s Term Nears End
node.description: New developments suggest the long-running inquiry has returned to an earlier focus: the valuations the former president and his family business applied to properties as it sought loans.

node.title: Italy announces new restrictions for the unvaccinated.
node.description: People who refuse a shot will be barred from a wide range of social activities, including indoor dining at restaurants and bars, and attending shows and sport events.

node.title: EU Worried New COVID Wave Could Disrupt Economic Recovery From Pandemic's Onset
node.description: "Our only message is: Take the situation very seriously, but without thinking that the economic impact will be the same one as one year ago," an official said.

node.title: Ex-Youth Football Coach Gets 45 Years For Recording His Sexual Abuse of 3 Minors
node.description: "Adults who use their access to children for their own sexual gratification...are both a danger and a disgrace," said FBI's Joseph Bonavolonta.

node.title: Video Shows Mob of Thieves Steal From Small Business Amid Bay Area Crime Wave
node.description: The store's owners said they "cannot operate as a business at the moment" on a GoFundMe page launched after the break-in.

node.title: Indoor air quality is a 'regulatory no-man's-land'. And that matters with COVID
node.description: There's lots of talk about fixing ventilation to stop COVID, but bad indoor air has been a problem for decades. How will this change, and what can we do in the meantime?

node.title: The controversial COVID posts fuelling a little known senator's popularity online
node.description: Liberal Senator Gerard Rennick has rapidly become the federal parliamentarian with the busiest Facebook page, thanks to his frequent posts about vaccines and COVID-19 lockdowns.

node.title: China's students are getting new school textbooks — and they reveal a lot about where China is headed
node.description: Xi Jinping's growing cultivation of a personality cult is reminiscent of the days of Mao Zedong, write Shih-Wen Sue Chen and Sin Wen Lau.

node.title: With one ill-fated answer, Morrison managed a double own goal
node.description: For prime ministers, parliamentary sitting weeks are often a bit like a visit to the dentist — something that must be endured. But this one has been particularly painful for Scott Morrison, writes David Speers.

node.title: Sarah campaigned to protect a patch of forest. Then a private investigator says he was told to find 'dirt' on her
node.description: The ABC can reveal VicForests hired a private investigator to conduct surveillance on conservationists and, more recently, conducted what some have called "digital surveillance" on people the agency argues are trying to "discredit" it.

node.title: Serko 'burning cash' as it prepares for growth out of pandemic
node.description: The travel software company's chief executive says it's poised for growth as more normal travel conditions resume.
